item.title: Mistakes, Bad Decisions, and Fallout
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: We've all made bad decisions. And while not everyone's mistakes end up on the front page of the newspaper, sending major policy initiatives offside, or derailing their futures, nobody likes to pick the wrong course of action. We explore what goes into making bad decisions and what can help avoid them?

item.title: Success Through Failure
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: When you're in the throes of it, failure never feels like something you want to embrace. But could sailing too quickly passed failure be a missed opportunity for a very good life lesson? Ashley Good, founder and CEO of the world's first failure consultancy, Fail Forward, explains why falling down is sometimes necessary for moving forward.

item.itunes:subtitle: McGill University economist Chris Ragan, chair of Canada's Ecofiscal Commission explains the group's final report exploring this country's options for reducing its greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Infrastructure Challenges in Ontario
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ontario government is pushing for more young people to enter the skilled trades. The announcement comes as major infrastructure projects such as transit and housing will put pressure on the industry to get projects completed on time and on budget. We look at how to get more people into skilled trades and whether or not Ontario has the labour power to get its planned work done.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Farmers in northern Ontario are asking for mental-health support due to help them cope with uncertainties with their crops. Northwestern Ontario Hubs reporter Jon Thompson tells us more.

item.title: Conservative Leadership Race Begins
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Three years ago, federal Conservatives gathered in Toronto and chose Saskatchewan's Andrew Scheer to be their leader, in a 13-ballot, 15-candidate marathon. We know how that story turned out. There's every indication when Conservatives pick a new leader in June, there will be many fewer ballots and candidates. What's the state of the race today?

item.title: Ontario's Municipal Finances
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: How do Ontario's cities make up for a shortfall in their budgets? Then, what will it take to reinvigorate the horse-racing industry in Ontario? We look at a new plan for policing animal cruelty. And, how is Canada dealing with the Iran plane crash tragedy.

item.title: Ontario's New Animal Protection Force
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: After 100 years, the enforcement of Ontario's animal cruelty laws will be handed from the Ontario Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (OSPCA) to a dedicated government team. That means new inspectors, stronger fines, jail terms, and an abuse hotline. We find out about the revamped system, the first of its kind in Canada.
item.itunes:summary: After 100 years, the enforcement of Ontario's animal cruelty laws will be handed from the Ontario Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (OSPCA) to a dedicated government team. item.title: Hurdles for Ontario Horse Racing
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In the last five years, the struggling Ontario horse-racing industry has received $500 million from Queen's Park so that it could stay afloat. However, the industry also employs thousands of Ontarians. What are the challenges facing the world's oldest spectator sport, what value does it provides to rural communities, and why is its relationship with the provincial government so fraught?

item.title: Iran, Canada, and the Consequences
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It will be a long time before the grief and mourning recedes after this month's downing of Flight 752 by the Iranian government, an act that killed 176 people, including 57 Canadians. As the Trudeau government and the international community grapple with how to deal with the regime in Iran, and find closure on the tragedy, we ask a panel of foreign affairs experts to share their expertise.

item.title: Syrian Refugees in Northern Ontario
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In 2017, the Alsalamat family fled civil war in Syria arriving in Sault Ste. Marie as refugees. Since then, there's been plenty of change in their lives: A new language, new schools, new jobs. Nearly three years later - the family couldn't imagine living anywhere else. Ontario Hubs field producer Jeyan Jeganathan hears their story of flight, arrival, and settlement.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Tonight, TVO's popular series Political Blind Date premiers its third season. Toronto city councilors Gary Crawford and Shelley Carroll, the current and former budget chiefs, talk to Steve Paikin about how best to dispense Toronto's budget during a time of cutbacks.

item.title: Should Billionaires be Taxed out of Existence?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Filmed on location at Victoria University at University of Toronto, this special episode of The Agenda poses the question: Should billionaires be taxed out of existence? Arguing yes are economist Armine Yalnizyan and journalist Linda McQuaig. On the no side are Sean Speer and Graeme Moffat of the Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy. The four engage in a spirited debate before a live audience on an issue about which many people feel strongly in an age of increasing economic inequality.

item.title: Ontario Education Labour Strife
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Education Minister Stephen Lecce discusses the latest developments between his office and the four Ontario teachers' unions currently taking job action. Catholic teachers are set to strike for one day next Tuesday, while elementary, secondary, and French teachers are continuing with their work-to-rule campaigns. What will it take to reach an agreement?

item.title: Children's Well-Being: Towards 2030
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The past decade has been a bad one for children in humanitarian crises around the globe, particularly in terms of food sustainability. Can the situation improve in the 2020s? David Morley, president of UNICEF Canada; Kim Snow, associate professor in the Faculty of Community Services at Ryerson; and Lindsay Groves, of Right to Play, join Steve Paikin to discuss how to make the world a safer place for the next generation.

item.title: A Children's Ambassador
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The UNICEF ambassador grew up in the most stressful of situations: a child living amid war-torn Beirut. Today, Yammout uses this experience and her skills as a teacher to help children in need.

item.title: The Political Price of Climate Inaction
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: As bush fires rage in Australia, a political backlash to Prime Minister Morrison and his views on climate change is mounting. And here in Canada a recent study found that if environmental views hadn't mattered in the 2019 federal election, the Conservatives might have fared better. Is there now a steep political price to be paid for climate inaction?

And here in Canada a recent study found that if environmental views hadn't mattered in the 2019 federal election, the Conservatives might have fared better. Is there now a steep political price to be paid for climate inaction?

item.title: Adam Shoalts: Crossing the Arctic Alone
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: From Yukon to Baker Lake, Nunavut, it's 4000 punishing, wind-swept kilometres across the entire Arctic. You'll need to arrive before winter hits. Oh, and you'll be doing it alone. But don't fear, you'll have a canoe. That's the challenge Adam Shoalts gave himself in 2017. He shares his experience and discusses his book, "Beyond the Trees."

item.title: Happiness at Work
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: When did it become an employer's responsibility to make sure its employees are happy at work? What's the science behind the idea that a content employee is a more productive one? We look at this emerging trend from an academic, business, and lived experience perspective.

item.title: Catherine Gildiner: Psychological Heroes
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: What happens between a therapist and their patients is both private and profound. Catherine Gildiner has been a clinical psychologist for more than 25 years, and in her new book, "Good Morning, Monster," she lets readers in on the recovery of five patients, whom she calls "heroic."

item.title: An Urban Future for Innisfil
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Drive 60 kilometres north of Toronto and you'll find the Town of Innisfil. In terms of area, it's roughly the size of Mississauga, but with less than one-twentieth of the population. Late last year, a new GO station in the town got its funding, and with it, an opportunity to build something innovative-and to redefine what Innisfil looks like. To outline the new "Orbit" project, we welcome: Lynn Dollin, mayor of Innisfil; and Jason Reynar, the town's chief administrative officer.

item.title: Moving the Masses in a Growing GTA
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: According to a census projection report commissioned by the Ontario government, the Greater Toronto Area population is expected to grow from 6.8 million in 2018 to over 10.2 million by 2046. How do you move that number of people around a region originally built for a much smaller population? Transit and transportation experts suggest how to keep people moving effectively and efficiently.

item.title: Riding the Great Lakes
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Storm conditions on the Great Lakes make them ideal for surfing, even in below zero temperatures. Toronto resident Antonio Lennert, founder and CEO of Surf the Greats, learned to surf on the ocean but discovered he could ride the waves in Lake Ontario. That led him to fostering a local surfing community, holding training sessions, and opening a store to cater to the specific needs of lake surfing. He talks to Jeyan Jeganathan about the joys and risks of surfing on a lake rather than an ocean.

item.title: Dealing With Existential Dread
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Brush fires ravaging Australia. Rising tensions and tragedy in Iran. Tumultuous politics everywhere. It can be difficult to remain hopeful when the world seems so chaotic. item.itunes:subtitle: The Agenda welcomes Matthew Fisher, Canada's longest-serving foreign correspondent, and Ann Fitz-Gerald, director of the Balsillie School of International Affairs and an internationally recognized security advisor, to discuss geopolitical events of 2019, and what they signal for the new year.

item.title: The Podcaster of Past Times
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan Carlin has taught people about some of history's greatest moments, but he's not a historian, nor a teacher. Carlin's blockbuster podcasts Hardcore History and Common Sense have reached millions of people, addicted to the tales he weaves. The Agenda welcomes Carlin to discuss his first book, "The End Is Always Near: Apocalyptic Moments, from the Bronze Age Collapse to Nuclear Near Misses."

item.title: The Undoing of History
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: University enrollment in history majors has slid farther and faster than most any other humanities discipline. Yet, popular engagement with history is thriving through podcasts and documentaries. The Agenda discusses what's going on, particularly in a time that desperately needs reliable historical knowledge?

item.title: Cathy Crowe: Memoirs of a Street Nurse
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Chronic homelessness is a problem in Ontario and despite government funding, it doesn't seem to be getting any better. What are we doing wrong? Cathy Crowe, distinguished visiting practitioner in the Faculty of Arts at Ryerson University and the author of "A Knapsack Full of Dreams: Memoirs of a Street Nurse," provides a greater understanding of the problem.

item.title: A Better Way to Battle Bullying
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: People across the province are continuing to ask questions following the death of Devan Bracci-Selvey. The 14-year-old was stabbed outside his high school in Hamilton last October after a series of bullying incidents. With more and more parents and students speaking out about the incidences of bullying in Ontario schools, The Agenda explores why bullying remains so prevalent and what can be done to help.

item.title: Canada's Challenges in the Arctic
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Whether from climate change, the drive for resource extraction, or tensions with global competitors such as Russia, the Arctic is increasingly a strategic pressure point. How should Canada position itself on these and other issues? To discuss this, The Agenda welcomes Michael Byers, the Canada Research Chair in Global Politics and International Law at the University of British Columbia and author of two books on the Arctic.

item.title: The Faces of Pediatric Palliative Care
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Losing a child is a parent's worst nightmare. As a children's hospice, Emily's House provides comfort for families living with those realities, day in and day out. Ontario Hubs field producer Jeyan Jeganathan visited the Toronto-based care centre - one of only two in the province - to understand those challenges, but also the issues of raising money for a cause that's difficult to talk about.

item.title: Distilling the State of an Industry
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Andrea Fujarczuk is the only full-time instructor at Canada's first artisanal distilling program, located at Niagara College. She visits The Agenda to delve into the state of the distilling industry in Ontario, and what it's like being at the forefront of this industry.

item.title: Brewing Up a Giant Corporation
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Labatt's is one of the most recognizable beer companies in the world, but it began as a small Canadian company. Matthew Bellamy traces that history in his new book, "Brewed in the North: A History of Labatt's," and he shares some of his research with Steve Paikin.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: experience is changing, particularly for box office-revenue with the rise of streaming giants such as Amazon, Netflix, Apple TV+, HBO, and Disney+ dominance. item.title: The Artist Known as Prince
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: When musician Prince died on April 21, 2016, he left scores of fans in mourning. But he also left behind pages of an unfinished memoir that tried to answer some questions about the his life and career. Editor Dan Piepenbring worked with Prince before he died, and he's put together a book that frames their working relationship as well as the beginning of Prince's life in "The Beautiful Ones."

item.title: Making Political Party Nominations Fair
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Many are familiar with how we elect our representatives in Ontario, but how did they get chosen by their party in the first place? It can be a messy, confusing, disorganized, and some charge, corrupt, process. PC MPP Belinda Karahalios aims to fix that. She chats with Steve Paikin about her private members' bill, Ensuring Transparency and Integrity in Political Party Elections Act.

item.title: The Science of Generosity
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It's the season of giving, but what makes some people more generous than others, even if they have less to give? The Agenda explores the science of generosity, including what determines who gives, where and how they give, as well as the effects of charity.

item.title: Christianity and the Religious Divide
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: With religiosity on the decline, what binds those who believe to their faith? Michael Coren, author of the new book "Reclaiming Faith: Inclusion, Grace, and Tolerance,"shares his views with Steve Paikin.

item.title: Volunteers Wanted!
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Are Canadians in the giving spirit these days? What are the modern-day barriers that might lead to fewer people offering their time to charitable causes? To learn about the state of volunteering in Canada, The Agenda welcomes Neil Hetherington, CEO of the Daily Bread Food Bank; Rafael Gomez, director of the University of Toronto's Centre for Industrial Relations and Human Resources; Joanne Mckiernan, executive director of Volunteer Toronto; and Katherine Alexopoulos, director of Volunteer Resources.

item.title: The Most Beloved Maple Leaf Ever
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Who is the greatest Toronto Maple Leaf of all time? It's a question that could prompt a fiery debate among the supporters of Mats Sundin, Darryl Sittler, or Davie Keon. But, what about star goaltender Johnny Bower. Dan Robson talks to Steve Paikin about his book, "Bower: A Legendary Life," in which he chronicles Bower's rise to fame and his place in hockey.

item.title: Making Art, Making a Living
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Artists pursue their crafts for many and varied reasons. And while some are rewarded with fame and fortune, most struggle to have the space and time to make the kind of work they want to share with the public. At $25,000, the inaugural Johanna Metcalf award is a generous prize. It was given just last night to five Ontario-based performing artists. It will give them - and another artist of their choosing - more opportunity to create. Joining The Agenda are playwright and theatre creator Sunny Drake; composer and classical pianist Alice Ping Yee Ho; composer James Rolfe; multidisciplinary artist Santee Smith; and world music performer and composer Maryem Tollar.

item.title: Ontario Hubs:Indigenous Allies
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Every two weeks for the past few months, non-Indigenous people gather at the Kind Space in Ottawa to read and discuss the Missing and Murdered Women and Girls final report. Shelby Lisk, our Ontario hubs journalist reporting on Indigenous issues, attended a meeting to learn how the supportive environment is cultivating understanding, reconciliation, and allyship.

item.title: Elisa Citterio: The New Baroque
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: They say if you want to be successful, don't be the person who replaces the legend. Be the person who replaces the person who replaces the legend. Obviously, Elisa Citterio didn't get that memo. 18 months ago, she became music director for the Tafelmusik Ensemble, taking over for Jeanne Lamon who'd performed that same role for 33 years. The Agenda welcomes the new maestro and finds out what she has in store for the popular ensemble.

item.title: Clarinet and Accordion
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Steve Paikin is joined by musicians Michael Bridge and Kornel Wolak. Bridge plays the accordion and Wolak plays the clarinet, and together, they make music that's a unique blend of baroque, classical, folk, and contemporary music.

item.title: Superstars of a Bygone Era
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: On the surface, they had not very much in common, other than the fact that they were both superstar female entertainers from decades ago. But Edith Piaf and Marlene Dietrich were both deeply emotional, and remarkably complicated women who thrilled millions with their talent, while their personal lives were frequently in turmoil. Louise Pitre and Jayne Lewis are portraying these two giants, on stage at Toronto's CAA Theatre until early January and they talk to Steve Paikin about what the two women they portray mean to them.

item.title: The Agenda: Education Matters
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: With Ontario elementary teachers on work to rule and another day-long walk out for high school teachers today, pressure is mounting on all sides to reach a contract deal. It only adds to the existing sense of urgency to get better outcomes - particularly in math - for kids from kindergarten to grade 12. The Agenda discusses ideas for how that can be achieved with Annie Kidder, executive director, People for Education; Karen Robson, associate professor and Ontario Research Chair in Educational Achievement and At-Risk Youth at McMaster University; and Globe and Mail education reporter Caroline Alphonso.

item.title: Medics in the Line of Fire
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Military historian Ted Barris has chronicled some of Canada's most important military moments, including The Battle of Vimy Ridge, D-Day, The Great Escape, and the Korean War. He talks to Steve Paikin about his latest book, "Rush to Danger: Medics in the Line of Fire," an exploration of his father's wartime experiences as a medic leading up to the Second World War's Battle of the Bulge in 1944-45.

item.title: Hugh Segal: A Lifelong Fight Against Poverty
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Hugh Segal has been on The Agenda many times, talking about why, as a conservative, he favors the creation of a basic income program for people experiencing poverty. What he hasn't discussed is how he came to that position, thanks to his own hardscrabble upbringing in Montreal, as the son of a cab driver who died when Segal was just 14 years old. He talks to Steve Paikin about his experiences, the topic of his new book, "Boot Straps Need Boots: One Tory's Lonely Fight to End Poverty in Canada."

item.title: The Internet's Mid-Life Crisis
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In the 1990s the internet was thought of as democratic and anarchic. Then came social media giants such as Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram; political movements such as the Arab Spring; and Amazon and Google galvanized the attention spans of millions of users. The Agenda looks at the internet's original promise, its milestones, and the future of the hyper-connected world.

item.title: A Wealth Tax in Canada?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: According to a 2018 Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives report, the wealthiest 87 families in Canada have as much wealth as the bottom 12 million Canadians. In the fall federal election, the NDP proposed a 1 per cent wealth tax for families with assets over $20 million, which would include approximately 6,000 families. Is a wealth tax fair? Would it be effective, or do more harm than good? The Agenda examines both sides of the argument.
item.itunes:summary: According to a 2018 Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives report, the wealthiest 87 families in Canada have as much wealth as the bottom 12 million Canadians. In the fall federal election, the NDP proposed a 1 per cent wealth tax for families with assets over $20 million, which would include approximately 6,000 families. Is a wealth tax fair? Would it be effective, or do more harm than good? The Agenda examines both sides of the argument.

item.title: Should Billionaires Exist?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Are billionaires such as Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates the American Dream personified? Do they reflect a healthy economy? Or, as Senator Bernie Sanders has said, should billionaires not exist in the first place? Anand Giridharadas, Time magazine editor-at-large and author of "Winners Take All: The Elite Charade of Changing the World," discusses why he agrees with Sanders. As well, he gives his take on the Democratic hopefuls and whether or not any one of them can beat Donald Trump.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Sault Ste. Marie has two bylaw officers to cover a population of approximately 75,000 people, and a backlog of complaints. Northeastern Ontario Hub journalist Nick Dunne reports on why it's a problem for a city to have so few officers to service bylaw issues.

item.title: #MeToo: Breaking the Harvey Weinstein Story
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It's been just over two years since a New York Times investigation into film mogul Harvey Weinstein was published, opening a floodgate for more stories of sexual assault and harassment. Megan Twohey, one of the reporters behind the investigation and co-author of the new book "She Said: Breaking the Sexual Harassment Story that Helped Ignite a Movement," joins The Agenda to discuss the story behind the story and her thoughts on the future of the #MeToo movement.

item.title: A More Profitable Paradigm
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Governments, theoretically, are in the business of solving problems. And oftentimes, despite throwing billions of dollars at these problems, progress is slow. But what if we're asking the wrong question. What if instead of asking governments to pay for various investments, we asked them if they wanted to save money? Shaun Loney describes this new paradigm in "The Beautiful Bailout: How a Social Innovation Scale-up Will Solve Government's Priciest Problem," and he joins The Agenda to explain.

item.title: The Montreal Massacre's Legacy for Engineers
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: 30 years ago, 14 female engineering students were killed by a ranting gunman at Montreal's cole Polytechnique. It remains the worst mass shooting in Canadian history and it changed the country in many ways, from a second look at gun laws to a greater awareness of misogyny. The Agenda discusses the legacy of the tragic event and what progress the country has made on violence against women, particularly in the area of engineering and other traditionally male domains.

item.title: Huawei's Uncertain Canadian Future
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It's been one year since Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou was taken into Canadian custody. The Trudeau government and the security community are still trying to determine whether the tech company can be trusted to build Canada's next-generation 5G wireless network infrastructure, while keeping Canadians' data safe. The Agenda welcomes Alykhan Velshi, head of corporate affairs at Huawei Canada, to respond to the intense criticism the company continues to face.

item.title: A Fractured Canada-China Relationship
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In the year since Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou was taken into Canadian custody, diplomatic relations between the Canada and China remain tense and marked by imprisonments, trade bans, and fiery rhetoric. The Agenda discusses how much progress has been made and the path towards a more amicable future.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Economist Armine Yalnizyan went from analyzing government data to helping make it, as she took a role with the federal government in Ottawa. She's now the Atkinson Foundation's Fellow on the Future of Workers, and she joins The Agenda to talk about the economic and social issues related to the changing nature of work.

item.itunes:subtitle: The political battle over pipelines shows no sign of stopping. And how does Canada balance economic concerns with the effects of fossil fuels on the environment.

item.title: Whatever Happened to Ambrose Small
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It remains one of Ontario's enduring mysteries. On December 2, 1919, theatre magnate Ambrose Small completed a deal of a lifetime. After selling his Ontario-wide theatre network, Small banked $1 million and promised to be home for dinner - and then he disappeared from sight. No one confessed to a crime, his body never turned up, and leads went nowhere. The Agenda welcomes Toronto Star reporter Katie Daubs, who became fascinated with this story and chronicled it in her book, "The Missing Millionaire: The True Story of Ambrose Small and the City Obsessed with Finding Him."

item.title: Charlotte Gray: A Millionaire's Murder Mystery
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Sir Harry Oakes, a major figure in 19th-and-early 20th century northern Ontario, made millions in mining. He was mysteriously murdered in the Caribbean in 1943, with no clues as to the culprit. The Agenda explores Oakes's intriguing life, and the mark he made on Kirkland Lake with historian Charlotte Gray, who chronicled his activities in her book, "Murdered Midas: A Millionaire, His Gold Mine, and a Strange Death on an Island Paradise."

item.title: The Crisis in Hong Kong
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Civil unrest has rocked Hong Kong for six months with violent clashes between police and demonstrators. The Agenda looks at the city's political crisis and its challenge to Beijing's rule with Emily Lau, former Democratic Party member of the Hong Kong Legislative Council and chair of the Hong Kong Democratic Party's foreign affairs committee.

item.title: Vic Fedeli: From Money Man to Job Creator
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: As finance minister in the Doug Ford government, Vic Fedeli delivered his first budget last April, only to have it receive a storm of criticism over controversial cuts. In the subsequent cabinet shuffle, Fedeli found himself with a new portfolio - economic development, job creation, and trade. His responsibilities recently took him to the Far East and South Asia to drum up some infrastructure jobs for Ontarians. He talks to Steve Paikin about his experiences.

item.title: Did the Pit Bull Ban Work?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In 2005 the former Liberal government banned pit bulls in Ontario, but 14 years later there are still pit bulls in the province. Now, the PC government is revisiting the controversial ban that has dog owners and non-dog owners undecided. Ontario Hubs field producer Jeyan Jeganathan spoke to industry experts about why they believe the ban hasn't worked well and the focus should be on responsible ownership.

item.title: Fighting For A Barrier-Free Ontario
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Twenty-five years ago, a group of 20 Ontarians with various disabilities gathered at Queen's Park with a mission: to push the province to commit future governments to make Ontario as barrier-free as possible. The Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act became law in 2005 and set stringent goals and deadlines. The Agenda welcomes David Lepofsky, chair of the AODA Alliance, and Thea Kurdi, vice-president at DesignABLE Environments, an accessible-design organization, to discuss what progress has been made.

item.title: Chronicling Ontario's Residential Institutions
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Ten years ago, the doors of Ontario's last residential institution closed. It was the final chapter in decades of public policy that saw people with developmental disabilities isolated from the community, and where some experienced abuse and neglect. Catherine McKercher's brother Bill was a resident of one of those institutions. She joins The Agenda to discuss her book, "Shut Away: When Down Syndrome was a Life Sentence."

item.title: Highways and our Transportation Future
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ontario government announced plans to revive the Greater Toronto Area West Highway, also known as Highway 413. Called the missing link in Toronto-area highways, GTA West is meant to address congestion and bring relief to drivers. But is adding another highway the right approach to changing transportation landscape? The Agenda looks at the pros and cons of the proposal

item.title: Bridging Ontario's Urban-Rural Divide
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Included in the Ontario government's fall economic statement was a commitment to regional economic development. Two reports by Ontario 360, a project by the Munk School of Global Affairs, examine Ontario's rural-urban divide and what policy options exist to bridge the gap, including Opportunity Zones. The Agenda spoke with two of the authors, Sean Speer and Weseem Ahmed, about their findings.

item.title: The Power of Nostalgia
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The last few years have seen nostalgia come to dominant popular culture. From the "Star Wars" film sequels, to the video game Pokmon Go, and the classic sitcom "Friends" becoming one of the most streamed shows on Netflix, a person would be forgiven for forgetting it isn't the '90s. The Agenda explores the power of nostalgia, why it's more popular than ever, and how companies are harnessing that power.

item.title: Amazon's Counterfeit Problem
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: This week will usher in one of the busiest shopping days of the year, Black Friday. According to market research company eMarketer, Canadians are on track to spend $64.56 billion shopping online by the end of 2019, with the largest destination being Amazon. The popularity of online shopping has led to a rise in counterfeit products, and it's not just luxury goods. It can be everything from cell-phone chargers and toys, to toothbrushes and other everyday items. The Agenda explores the issue, and why it's getting harder to tell the difference between what's real and what's fake online.

item.title: Ontario Hubs: Reviving Lost Languages
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian McCallum, an Indigenous language educator and Shelby Lisk, our Ontario Hubs reporter on Indigenous issues, have both embarked on learning the languages of their family ancestry. For McCallum that's Lunaape, and he's one of only a handful of people who understand it. For Lisk, it's Mohawk. They talk to Jeyan Jeganathan about their journeys to unlock their culture and history through language and why it's important for Indigenous languages to re-emerge and be preserved.

item.title: Elementary Teachers at the Bargaining Table
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The collective agreements for teachers in Ontario expired at the start of the school year. The teachers' unions and ministry representatives have been at the bargaining table to reach consensus. But, with no agreement reached, the Elementary Teachers' Federation of Ontario will begin work-to-rule action next week. ETFO president Sam Hammond talks to Steve Paikin about what's at stake.

item.itunes:subtitle: The Agenda welcomes Ontario's Attorney General Doug Downey to discuss how the PC government is managing the province's justice system, including the rollout of cannabis retail stores, and changes to legal-aid funding.

item.title: Post-legalization Pot Losses
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: A year after cannabis legalization in Canada, The Agenda examines the industry's rough start -- particularly in Ontario. To examine what went wrong and what the future of cannabis could look like, Steve Paikin speaks with Bruce Linton, the founder and former CEO of Canopy Growth, the world's largest cannabis company; Financial Post reporter Vanmala Subramaniam; Jay Rosenthal of Business of Cannabis; and Pamela Jeffery of the Ontario Cannabis Policy Council.

item.title: The Minority Players
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The last time Canada had a minority federal government was 11 years ago. That's a long time in politics, so here is a look at how it might work. The Agenda welcomes several observers with first-hand experience with a minority government: former Conservative cabinet minister, Peter MacKay; Martha Hall Findlay, who served in the last minority parliament as the Liberal MP; Peggy Nash, former NDP MP; along with Peter Loewen, political science professor at the Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy.

item.title: Jane Philpott: The Trail Less Travelled
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Before she was the member of parliament for Markham-Stouffville, Jane Philpott was a family doctor, a professor and chief of Family Medicine at Markham Stouffville Hospital. In 2015, she was part of Justin Trudeau's sunny ways team, elected to do politics differently. As part of the first ever 50/50 male/female cabinet, she was appointed minister of health, where she oversaw some substantial legislative initiatives. Then came the SNC-Lavalin matter, and a decision on principle to leave the Liberal party. Philpott talks to Steve Paikin about her decisions and her bid to gain an independent seat in last month's election.

item.title: Prey: Taking on the Catholic Church
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: This powerful documentary shines light on Fr. William Hodgson Marshall, a Canadian priest convicted in 2011 of abusing several students over three decades at schools in Rochester, Toronto, Windsor, Sudbury, and Sault Ste. Marie. A TVO Original documentary, "Prey" won top honours at the 2019 Hot Docs Festival. The Agenda discusses this unforgettable film which focuses on survivor Rod MacLeod's legal fight against the Catholic church in Ontario. MacLeod and fellow survivor Patrick McMahon, who was the first to file a criminal complaint against Marshall, talk to Nam Kiwanuka, along with director Matt Gallagher; producer Cornelia Principe; and lawyer Rob Talach, also known as the "priest hunter."

item.title: Why Conservatives and Liberals Think Differently
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It may be obvious that people who identify politically as liberals and conservatives think differently because they disagree on issues ranging from immigration to climate change policy. But what are the deeper psychological roots that drive their political beliefs? In the aftermath of the federal election, the Agenda explores the conservative mind vs. the liberal mind.

item.title: Ziya Tong: We Are Blind to Most of Reality
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Science journalist Ziya Tong talks about her book, "The Reality Bubble: Blind Spots, Hidden Truths, and the Dangerous Illusions That Shape Our World." In it she explores blind spots in individuals and in human existence and how being in the dark when it comes to how we survive makes it impossible to navigate our future.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin

item.title: The Trouble with Tarion
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: If you purchased a newly-built home in Ontario in the past 40 years or so, it likely came with warranty protection from the Tarion Warranty Corporation. It is sometimes the last hope for consumers locked in disputes with developers and homebuilders. But Tarion is not without its critics, and earlier this year, Ontario's Auditor General Bonnie Lysyk delved into the company's activities. She talks to Steve Paikin about what she found.

item.title: Emily Nussbaum: Television is Great
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In 2016, Emily Nussbaum, the New Yorker's television critic, won the Pulitzer Prize for Criticism. Was this a sign that the entertainment genre, characterized as lower-brow in the past, had entered a renaissance in popularity and legitimacy as a dominant form of story-telling. Nussbaum talks to Steve Paikin about her book, "I Like to Watch: Arguing My Way Through the TV Revolution."

item.title: Salman Rushdie: A Quixotic Tale
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Few writers would have the self-confidence to re-imagine the classic "Don Quixote," often referred to as the first modern novel. But there are few writers like Salman Rushdie. His newest novel, "Quichotte," takes readers on an equally epic journey, exploring the dilemmas of a world that has lost its grip on the truth.

item.title: How To Govern Ontario's Regions
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Last year, the PC government announced it would be reviewing several Ontario regions to determine whether the five-decades-old lines needed to be re-drawn to help municipalities deliver services effectively. A report was commissioned and delivered, but then the government shelved it without announcing or implementing any of the recommendations. The Agenda discusses the state of the regions and what some mayors would like to see change.

item.title: The Secret Plot to Bring the U.S. into WWII
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: At the outset of the Second World War, the Allies were desperate to have Americans fight alongside them. So, they enlisted Canadian M16 officer William Stephenson to help sway them, kicking off a large-scale, state-sponsored influence campaign. Author Henry Hemming joins The Agenda to discuss his book, "Agents of Influence: A British Campaign, a Canadian Spy, and the Secret Plot to Bring American into World War II."

item.title: Northern Ontario's WWII Sacrifices
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Soldiers from northern Ontario contributed a great deal to the Second World War but little has been written specifically about them. A new book titled "Untold: Northeastern Ontario's Military Past, Volume 2" helps Ontario readers understand the sacrifices. Co-author Dieter K. Buse, a former Royal Canadian Air Force drill instructor, recounts some memorable stories about what soldiers were responsible for and what they endured.

item.title: Ottawa's Light Rail Roll-Out
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In September, Ottawa launched its brand-new LRT line. The weeks after have been filled with delays, service interruptions, and overcrowded stations. With several other Ontario cities, including Hamilton, Toronto, and Mississauga, set to get their own light rail systems in the coming years, The Agenda looks at how Ottawa's roll-out has gone and what pain points are to be expected in any new transit infrastructure construction.

item.title: Toronto's Risky Roads
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: According to the Toronto Police Service, 51 people have been killed in road collisions in 2019. Now, with fewer daylight hours those numbers will likely only rise. For some, the number of incidents is symbolic of a growing aggression on the city's streets. The Agenda looks at the reasons for this aggression and how the streets can be made safer for everyone.

item.title: Autism Plan Recommendations for Ontario
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In the early days of Ontario PC government's mandate, major changes were proposed to programs and services for children with autism. That prompted a huge reaction from families and experts, which led to a policy reversal, the shuffling of the cabinet minister responsible, and the creation of a task force to recommend a better way forward. Last week, the report of the Ontario Autism Program Advisory Panel came in. The Agenda welcomes the panel co-chairs, Margaret Spoelstra, executive director of Autism Ontario; and Marie Bountrogianni, former Ontario minister of children and youth, to discuss the findings and recommendations.

item.title: Addressing Police Mental Health and Suicide
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: When nine Ontario officers died by suicide in 2018, the province's chief coroner Dr. Dirk Huyer assembled an advisory committee to try to understand what the root causes were and recommend solutions. Psychologist Dr. Lori Gray, one of the contributors to the subsequent report, found police work culture to be an important part of the issue. They join an Agenda discussion on the shift in perspective that's needed in police work.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin

Ontario Hubs reporters Jon Thompson and David Rockne Corrigan talk to Jeyan Jeganathan about the province's spookier characteristics.

item.title: The Return of the Bloc Qubcois
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The Bloc Qubcois surged to third place in the federal election. How did the party that promotes Quebec sovereignty pull it off? What role did the controversial Bill 21 and pipelines play in the victory? The Agenda welcomes Stphanie Chouinard of Queen's University, and Emily Laxer of York University's Glendon College to discuss the role the Bloc will play in a minority government.

item.title: What the West Wants
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Reaction out of western Canada to last week's election outcome was swift and, at times, fierce. #Wexit trended on Twitter for days, as some outraged voices in Alberta and Saskatchewan saw the Liberal minority win as the final straw, and cause to pursue a separatist exit from Canada. For voters in Ontario, who took some of the wrath, it can be a bit puzzling. To help us understand, The Agenda welcomes a panel of experts on western Canada's relationship with Ottawa.

item.title: An Adoption Journey
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Ten years ago, Jenny Heijun Wills travelled to South Korea in hopes of reuniting with her birth parents and to answer the essential question: Why did they put her up for adoption? Her memoir of family and identity reveals what she found out and tells of the journey that led her to an even more profound relationship. Steve Paikin talks to Wills, an associate professor of English at the University of Winnipeg and the author of "Older Sister, Not Necessarily Related," which was recently shortlisted for the 2019 Writers' Trust Award.

item.title: Adoption Options
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: For many years, Canadian families adopted children from China and other counties. But, with the changes to China's one-child policy and other global efforts to keep children in their country of origin, international adoptions by Canadians have plummeted. The Agenda discusses what the options are for families who wish to adopt children from countries other than Canada.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: With the Liberals back for a second term, how will Canada handle relations with the U.S., China, and other countries? How will the Trudeau government navigate difficult international challenges from climate change to arctic sovereignty? The Agenda examines what direction our foreign policy may head in under a minority parliament.

item.title: The Mystery of Mental Illness
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Is mental illness a biological condition? And has that assumption paved a path that, despite good intentions, has often resulted in failed treatments and worse? Those are the questions that animate Anne Harrington's new book, "Mind Fixers: Psychiatry's Troubled Search for the Biology of Mental Illness." Harrington, a professor of the history of science at Harvard University, joins The Agenda to discuss her research.

item.title: Living with Depression and Suicidal Thoughts
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In addition to being a taboo topic, suicide also used to be something the media did not cover. For journalist and author Anna Mehler Paperny however, the topic is a personal one. And in her new book, "Hello I Want to Die Please Fix Me: Depression in the First Person," she endeavours to destigmatize that very difficult conversation. She joins The Agenda to discuss her personal and journalistic journey.

item.title: Tegan and Sara: The Agony and Ecstasy of the Teen Years
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Identical twins Tegan and Sara Quin started making music in mid-'90s Calgary, where they were born and grew up. Since then, they've won Juno awards, a Governor General's Award, and performed at the Oscars. While they were busy doing all that, they've also been out advocates for LGBTQ rights, launching the Tegan and Sara Foundation in 2016 to advance issues of economic justice and health for LGBTQ girls and women. They join Steve Paikin to talk about their new album and memoir, both of which head back to the high school days where their journeys began.

item.title: One Last Look at the Polls
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Election day is Monday. Most polls show a virtual tie between the Liberals and the Conservatives. Does Polly, the artificial intelligence algorithm, have a more definitive view of what's to come? Erin Kelly is CEO of Advanced Symbolics Inc., and as she's done throughout this federal campaign, she's joins The Agenda to discuss what Polly is picking up as the race comes to a close.

item.title: Pat Sorbara: A Life in Backroom Politics
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Pat Sorbara spent more than 40 years trying to get Liberals elected to much success. But despite helping Kathleen Wynne win a majority government victory in 2014, she found herself on the outs four years later. She tells Steve Paikin that story and more from her memoir, "Let 'Em Howl: Lessons from a Life in Backroom Politics."

item.title: The Breast Screening Debate
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Earlier this year, The Agenda featured an interview with journalist Renee Pellerin about her new book, ,Conspiracy of Hope., The gist of the book is that too many women are going for unnecessary mammograms. It was a controversial book and prompted a dissenting email to the show from Dr. Paula Gordon, a clinical professor in the radiology department at the University of British Columbia, and senior radiologist at the Sadie Diamond Breast Program at B.C. Women's Hospital and Health Care. So, in the interest of equal time, The Agenda welcomes Dr. Gordon for the other side of the debate.

item.title: Conversation Deficit
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In past election campaigns, debt and deficits have dominated the conversation. Think of Paul Martin's demand in the 1990s to slay the deficit dragon ,come hell or high water., Even in the last federal election, the NDP ran on a promise of balancing the budget. This time around, concerns about debt and deficits are barely registering. The Agenda discusses why there is a conversation deficit about the country's debt.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: When you're dead, who inherits your twitter followers? Who controls your Instagram profile, or you're your online trading account? She joins The Agenda to talk about her book, "Your Digital Undertaker: Exploring Death in the Digital Age in Canada."

item.title: Jeffrey Simpson: Pondering Electoral Options
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Every election has its own rhythm: what issues matter, who gets traction, what does and doesn't end up defining the race. For more than 40 years, Jeffrey Simpson has watched politicians across Canada campaign. The Governor-General's award-winning author and former Globe and Mail national affairs columnist talks to Steve Paikin about his impressions of this year's race.

item.title: Dave Hill: Finding My Inner Canuck
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: American comedian, actor, and musician in the band Valley Lodge, Dave Hill is immensely proud of his one-quarter Canadian roots. Fuelled by his grandfather's assertion that Canada is the greatest nation on earth, Hill set out years later to discover the truth. The result is his book, "Parking the Moose: One American's Epic Quest to Uncover His Incredible Canadian Roots," and he talks to Steve Paikin about all he learned.

item.title: Robyn Doolittle: Calling Out Rape Culture

item.itunes:subtitle: For her 2017 Globe and Mail "Unfounded" series, Robyn Doolittle spent two years investigating how police and the courts handle sexual assault cases in Canada. Tonight, she talks to Nam Kiwanuka about how attitudes around sexual behaviour have changed and still need to change.

item.title: #MeToo At Two
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It's been two years since a New York Times expos brought Harvey Weinstein's alleged history of sexual harassment and assault into the open. The reaction was swift and resulted in a cultural reckoning. But what's happening now? The Agenda assesses where the worldwide movement took gender relations and how it has affected society, from personal and workplace relationships to policing and the courts.

item.title: Malcolm Gladwell: Rethinking Familiarity
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: On any given day, much of our communication is with people we don't know, or don't know well. Those interactions can sometimes be fraught with misunderstandings and misreading. Author, podcaster, and thought experimentalist Malcolm Gladwell has taken this idea and run with it in his first book in six years, "Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don't Know." Gladwell lays out social science research, applies it to current events and asks readers to rethink anything from police checks to Amanda Knox, Bernie Madoff, campus sexual assault, and terrorist interrogations. He talks to Steve Paikin about why we can't trust what we think we know when we meet unfamiliar people.

item.title: Evaluating Performance-based Funding
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ontario government, in its 2019 provincial budget, announced it will introduce performance-based funding for post-secondary institutions in 2020. The plan is for up to 60 per cent of funding for Ontario universities and colleges to eventually be tied to 10 performance targets. Joining Steve Paikin to discuss the plan and its potential implications for the quality of higher learning in the province are: Alex Usher of Higher Education Strategy Associates; and Nipissing University professor Gyllian Phillips on behalf of the Ontario Confederation of University Faculty (OCUFA).

item.title: The Lost Art of Reading
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Can you imagine getting a university education without books? While that may have happened some time ago in disciplines such as computer science or mathematics, it is now settling into areas where it once would have seemed impossible: the humanities, the arts, and social sciences. The Agenda discusses what that says about learning in the 21st century.

item.title: Is Canadian media losing its touch?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Media today is everywhere, online, on TV, radio, podcasts, even in elevators. That leaves it open to many critics; some bash media outlets and reporters for being elitist, while others bemoan the so-called click bait, dumbing-down of the news. Joining The Agenda to reflect on whether there's a widening gap between the press and the public are Suanne Kelman, professor emeritus of the Ryerson School of Journalism; and Chris Waddell, of Carleton University's School of Journalism and Communication.

item.title: The Uneasy Life of Girls
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The final year of high school can be a scary time in the lives of young women. Pressured to perform well at school, facing internal pressure to be perfect, and dealing with the mixed messages of how a girl should behave, young women today face more tangible and emotional hurdles than young men. The Agenda explores this new reality and how girls are dealing with these challenges.

item.title: Preparing for Flu Season
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Every year, many Ontarians roll up their sleeves to get the flu shot. The shot is prepared specifically to combat the strains expected to dominate that year. Experts say this season will be especially tough, and there's also word that the vaccine is delayed. To explain further, The Agenda welcomes Dr. Michelle Murti, public health physician with Public Health Ontario, and Jill Promoli, a flu prevention advocate.
item.itunes:summary: Every year, many Ontarians roll up their sleeves to get the flu shot. The shot is prepared specifically to combat the strains expected to dominate that year. Experts say this season will be especially tough, and there's also word that the vaccine is delayed. To explain further, The Agenda welcomes Dr. Michelle Murti, public health physician with Public Health Ontario, and Jill Promoli, a flu prevention advocate.

item.title: Addressing Vaccine Hesitancy
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: To attend school, children in Ontario must be vaccinated against several contagious diseases - from diphtheria to chicken pox, measles, mumps and some others. There are exceptions, for those immune-suppressed, but also for parents who object for other reasons. Now, the Toronto Board of Health is urging the province to end all non-medical exemptions for vaccinations. To explore this topic, The Agenda welcomes Dr. Vinita Dubey, associate Medical Officer of Health, Toronto Public Health; and Globe and Mail health reporter Carly Weeks.

item.title: Another Brexit Dustup
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Just when you think you've seen it all across the pond in Great Britain, the story has become even more bizarre. Yesterday, Britain's highest court ruled that prime minister Boris Johnson gave Queen Elizabeth illegal advice, when she prorogued Parliament earlier this month. To discuss this latest chapter in the Brexit saga, The Agenda welcomes Graham Gudgin, chief economic advisor Policy Exchange, London; and Ashley Prime, formerly a British diplomat to Canada.

item.title: Hitting Reset on the Ring of Fire
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The economic promise behind the Ring of Fire has been the dreams of Ontario governments and northern Ontarians alike for over a decade. After millions of dollars have been invested into the mineral rich region, the PC government has now decided to eliminate a regional agreement with nine united First Nations, preferring to deal with them on a one-on-one basis. The Agenda discusses the status of the project.

item.title: Moving Beyond the Green Energy Act
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: It's been a decade since the birth of the Green Energy Act, enacted by the McGuinty Liberal government in 2009. The legislation aimed to expand renewable energy production and create green jobs across the province. The PC government has scrapped the plan and cancelled its contracts. The Agenda discusses what the Green Energy Act accomplished and what is lost by its demise.

item.title: Jody Wilson-Raybould: An Unwavering Voice
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Steve Paikin's discussion with Canada's former attorney general and justice minister Jody Wilson-Rabould - taped before the Justin Trudeau brownface and blackface photos were revealed - encompasses her new book, "From Where I Stand: Rebuilding Indigenous Nations for a Stronger Canada," the part she played in the Liberal government's SNC Lavalin controversy, and her bid to win an independent seat on October 21 in Vancouver-Granville.

item.title: Indigenous Enfranchisement
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Indigenous people got full voting rights in Canada only in 1960. And ever since, it's been a serious question for many in those communities as to whether to participate in Canadian elections, and if so, how. To help explain the issues, The Agenda welcomes Grand Chief Serge Simon of the Mohawk Council of Kanesatake; Margaret Froh, president of the Mtis Nation of Ontario; and Riley Yesno, a member of Eabametoong First Nation and a student at the University of Toronto.

item.title: Ontario Hubs: London's Bicycle Mayor
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: How did London's Shelley Carr go from being a cycling advocate to one of only 40 bicycle mayors around the world. Southwestern Ontario Hub reporter Mary Baxter learns that after a serious car accident, Carr began using her bike as transportation and spreading the word about the virtues of cycling around the city. Soon she was nominated, then named bicycle mayor. In her role she pushes for biking infrastructure to ensure roads are safe for cyclists.

item.title: Canadians' Reactions to Trudeau's Actions
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: If ever a bombshell hit a Canadian election campaign, it happened this week. Photos of Justin Trudeau in blackface and brownface swirled a very complicated brew of opinion in the country. Erin Kelly is CEO of Advanced Symbolics Inc, and a skilled interpreter of what Polly, the artificial intelligence analyst, has been picking up on from hundreds of thousands of Canadians since that story broke. She talks to Steve Paikin about what Canadians are thinking about Trudeau in light of these revelations.

item.title: The Agenda's Week in Review
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The Great Lakes are beginning to be largely affected by climate change. A panel of experts tells us how. Then, how to keep French-language schools purely French. The Agenda reviews its week of programming.

item.title: Naomi Klein: The Case for a Green New Deal
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Author and activist Naomi Klein joins Steve Paikin to discuss her new book, "On Fire: The Burning Case of a Green New Deal," in which she makes the case for why a Green New Deal is a necessary framework for tackling climate collapse and economic inequality.

item.title: A Holistic View of Corporations
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Corporations are critical players in Canada's economy - they create the wealth, jobs, goods, and services we all need. And increasingly that's prompted people to see them as more than commercial enterprises, but as key social actors too. The Agenda welcomes Sarah Kaplan to discuss her new book, "The 360 degree Corporation: From Stakeholder Trade-offs to Transformation," about how businesses are confronting some of those new expectations.

item.title: The Forgotten Equine
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Since the early 1990s, the Donkey Sanctuary of Canada has given more than 200 abused and neglected donkeys a forever home. Ontario Hubs field producer Jeyan Jeganathan went to Puslinch to take a tour of the facility - and to find out how it's helping spark conversations about the oft-forgotten equine.

item.title: The End of Shareholder Primacy?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Last month, some of America's top business people released a statement saying, among other things: "CEOs work to generate profits and return value to shareholders, but the best-run companies do more." It was part of a wider call for change in how companies do business. Joining Steve Paikin in a discussion about success beyond profits is Phillip Haid, of the social impact marketing agency PUBLIC Inc.; Toby Heaps, of Corporate Knights Inc.; Tanya van Biesen, of the digital marketing agency Catalyst; and Sarah Kaplan, author of "The 360 degree Corporation: From Stakeholder Trade-offs to Transformation."

item.title: Securing French Language Education in Ontario
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: As the demand for French education in Ontario continues to grow, more anglophone parents are putting their children in the province's French language schools. Those school boards, which are protected by Charter rights, are now facing a possible constitutional challenge. The Agenda discusses what this means for Ontario's French schools.

item.title: Examining Education from Union Eyes
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The education file has proven to be a tough one for the Ontario PC government, and it doesn't appear to be getting any easier as the province and unions prepare to head to the bargaining table. The Agenda welcomes Harvey Bishchof, president of the Ontario Secondary School Teachers' Federation, to discuss what's at stake for teachers, the government, and ultimately students.

item.title: The Waning Power of the United States
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The United States has long been regarded as the "leader of the free world." But under President Trump, it's not quite inspiring the confidence it once did. And, some think it's even time for the U.S. dollar to be supplanted as the benchmark global currency. Joining The Agenda to discuss this notable change is Adam Tooze, author of the 2019 Gelber Prize-winning book, "Crashed: How a Decade of Financial Crises Changed the World."

item.title: Politics, Partisanship, and Polarization
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Canada has historically prided itself on its moderate political culture. Is that changing? Are divisions deepening because there is a shift in attitudes among Canadians at large, or is it the actions of the political class. To discuss how well federal parties represent the political feelings of citizens, The Agenda welcomes pollster Erin Kelly, and columnists Andrew Coyne and Tony Keller.

item.title: Great Lakes, Great Problems
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Dozens of residents in Chatham-Kent are cleaning up after high winds and high waters caused catastrophic flooding and destroyed homes. The overflowing lakes, and the damage caused by them, are just one of the issues facing the world's largest bodies of freshwater. The Agenda takes stock of the problems and why a new report is calling on the federal government for a $1 billion investment over the next decade to fix them.

item.title: The Highs and Lows of the Great Lakes
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: According to the federal government, levels on each of the Great Lakes reached near or above record highs every month this summer. That has left property-owners and businesses along the lakes incredibly concerned. However, just a few short years ago the worry was over low lake levels. Drew Gronewold, an associate professor of environment and sustainability at the University of Michigan, joins The Agenda to discuss why the swings between the highs and lows are becoming so volatile and how climate change is playing a role.

item.title: Checking In on the Great Lakes
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: For more than a century, Canada and the United States have worked together through the International Joint Commission (IJC) to protect one of North America's most valuable resources, the Great Lakes. In 2016, the IJC introduced a new plan to regulate water levels in Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River, which residents say has led to widespread flooding. Pierre Bland, IJC's Canadian chair and commissioner, joins The Agenda to discuss those concerns and other issues facing the Great Lakes.

item.title: Ontario Hubs: Voters of Tomorrow
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Student Vote is a national program that helps set students up to vote when they reach eligibility age. It teaches the political process with the added important component of helping them learn to decipher media messages, images, and misinformation. Eastern Ontario Hub reporter David Rockne Corrigan talks about how the program works and why it's important.

item.title: The Agenda's Week in Review
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: This week's review of Agenda episodes features solutions to seniors' housing dilemmas; how we can work together globally to fight climate change; a discussion of Toronto's rapid growth; and Ontario's very serious opioid fatalities problem.

item.title: The Warrior Gynecologist
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Jen Gunter is a Canadian-American obstetrician-gynecologist known for her outspokenness and ability to debunk misinformation about women's health. From correcting media information to celebrity lifestyle websites, Gunter is working to make sure the public is getting scientific information on vaginal health. She joins The Agenda to discuss her latest book, "The Vagina Bible."

item.title: Shared Housing: Affordable Living for Seniors
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Living with roommates isn't just for university students anymore: seniors such as Pat Dunn are starting to understand the benefits of pooling resources to live comfortably, too. Her Facebook group, Senior Ladies Living Together, connects potential roommates to save on rental costs and alleviate loneliness. Joining her to discuss this trend is Louise Bardswich, part of a group called the Golden Girls of Port Perry, who recently invested in a shared home.

item.title: The Right Homes for Seniors
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: In the blistering housing markets of southern Ontario one group that's often overlooked in the conversation is seniors. Some are living in houses that are too big and hard to maintain. Others can't find suitable AND affordable stock that allows them to downsize. And others still need new services and amenities that their neighbourhoods simply don't have. The Agenda discusses the issue of appropriate housing for seniors.

item.title: How High Can Toronto Go?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Is Toronto growing too much, too fast? Can the city's services keep up? Or, with nearly 100,000 people moving to the GTA yearly, is there not enough growth to accommodate them? The Agenda debates growth vs. affordability with Dave Wilkes, president and CEO with the Building Industry and Land Development Association; Kristyn Wong-Tam, city councillor for Toronto Centre; Joe Cressy, city councillor for Spadina-Fort York; and Eileen Costello, partner at Aird Berlis LLP.

item.title: Karen Stintz: A Voice in Politics
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Part of what makes a politician successful is his or her ability to convince you that they're trustworthy and authoritative. Would it surprise you to learn that studies show we equate trustworthiness and authoritativeness with lower voices? Karen Stintz learned that, when she was in local politics in the provincial capital from 2003 to 2014 and she joins us now for more.

item.title: Ontario's Opioid Crisis
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Opioid-related fatalities have increased dramatically in the last 10 years in Ontario - and the numbers are staggering. Every age, demographic and geographic profile has been affected. The Agenda looks at why it seems to be getting worse, what's being done about it, and how the province can work to reduce on future cases.

item.title: Opioids: Local Scourge, Global Network
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan Werb's Walrus article, "Oxy Town," published five years ago, revealed the grim situation unfolding in small Ontario communities hit by the opioid crisis, including his home region of Chatham-Kent. Werb, an epidemiologist and university professor, provides an update on the situation.

item.title: A Big Storm, A Warming Planet
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Hurricane Dorian devastated the Bahamas and affecting parts of the U.S. and Canada. Climatologist Michael Mann joins Steve Paikin to make the case for why these types of storms are only becoming more deadlier due to climate change.

item.title: State Sovereignty and Climate Change
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Brazil's president Jair Bolsonaro faced international criticism for his government's response to the fires that are raging across the Amazon, a vital resource in the fight against global warming. The Agenda's panel discusses whether state sovereignty is an outdated concept when it comes to fighting climate change, and if more action is needed to stop countries that put the environment at risk.

item.itunes:subtitle: Co-host of TVO's political podcast John Michael McGrath and producer Eric Bombicino discuss the upcoming season of episodes, which will be devoted entirely to covering the federal election. The series will get into Canadian populism, carbon pricing, the federal leaders' debates, and other top-of-mind issues to voters.

item.title: John Ivison: Educating the Prime Minister
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: From "just not ready," to leading Canada for the past five years, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau revived the Canadian Liberal Party and has pushed forth a progressive agenda. Along the way, he's suffered personal gaffes, caucus pains, and plenty of criticism. He's also had to navigate a diplomatic relationship with the unpredictable Donald Trump. Political columnist John Ivison puts the PM's leadership under consideration with his new book, "Trudeau: The Education of a Prime Minister."

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin

A group of journalists assess the Ford government as it enters its second year of helming the province. Finally, economic experts assess Canada's chance of surviving a recession.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Economic experts discuss the general health of the Ontario and Canadian economies, the effects of the U.S. trade war with China, the politics of the economy during an election year, and why a potential recession is on everyone's minds.

item.title: A Renewed Ford Government?
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Just before the Ontario legislature took its summer break, Premier Ford shuffled his cabinet. Shortly after, the government had to answer for a series of inappropriate patronage appointments. As summer wore on, policy announcements made headlines and the government's approval ratings dropped. The Agenda welcomes a panel of Queen's Park journalists to break down all the goings on over the last few months.

item.title: Christine Elliott: An Ontario Health Care Checkup
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Since taking office over a year ago, the Ontario PC government has made sweeping changes to the health-care system - amalgamating services, working to end hallway medicine - all while trying to find savings along the way. Steve Paikin gets an update from Christine Elliott, Ontario's minister of health.

item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: With teacher contract negotiations underway and changes to class sizes and curriculum, it's been a busy summer for the Ontario government. Kicking off The Agenda's 14th season, Stephen Lecce, minister of education and Progressive Conservative MPP for King-Vaughan talks to Steve Paikin about the work his ministry is doing.

item.title: A Critical Eye on Education
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: This summer, the Ontario government unveiled more details of planned changes to class sizes, math testing for teachers, and a revamped sex-ed curriculum. Not everyone is applauding the changes. Marit Stiles, opposition education critic and NDP MPP for Davenport, and Mitzie Hunter, former education minister and Liberal MPP for Scarborough-Guildwood join The Agenda to share their thoughts on the changes.

item.title: The Changing Role of School Principals
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: While the main roles of a school principal are supposed to be education and guiding the professional development of staff, many have reported finding themselves consumed with too much administrative work. Many say they spend the bulk of their time on everything from students' mental health to covering staffing shortages. The Agenda looks at how the role of a school principal has changed, and how students are affected.

item.title: Museum London Looks at Racism in the City's Past
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: The London museum's ,Difficult Terrain, exhibit uses dozens of objects and images to illuminate racist elements of the city's past. Over the years, the museum has amassed a collection of toys, postcards, and packages that perpetuate racist stereotypes - and, as Ontario Hubs field producer Jeyan Jeganathan explains, some of the attitudes and false assumptions behind them persist to this day.

item.title: Fighting the Kremlin

item.itunes:subtitle: Russian democracy activist Vladimir Kara-Murza has faced many trials in his life. He's been poisoned twice and nearly died, and he's lost his colleague and friend Russian opposition leader Boris Nemstsov to a hail of gunfire outside the Kremlin. Russian democracy activist Vladimir Kara-Murza has faced many trials in his life. He's been poisoned twice and nearly died, and he's lost his colleague and friend Russian opposition leader Boris Nemstsov to a hail of gunfire outside the Kremlin. Kara-Murza tells Steve Paikin about his efforts to rid Russia of corruption and find space for democracy to grow.

item.title: Canadian Politics Before the Fall
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Political interference? An erosion of trust? The back and forth over the SNC-Lavalin controversy crested today with the prime minister adding his perspective to that of all the other players who've made their views known over the past few weeks. It's all offered Canadians a fascinating and possibly unprecedented look behind the curtain of the prime minister's office. The Agenda considers what all this is doing to Justin Trudeau's brand, the opposition's standing, and how people will vote in the October federal election.

item.title: Battling Bias in Nutrition Research
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Marion Nestle, author of "Unsavory Truth: How Food Companies Skew the Science of What We Eat," talks with Nam Kiwanuka about how nutrition science can be slanted by the funding that researchers receive from food companies. Nestle also discusses the role that journalists can play in either spreading or exposing biased research findings.

item.title: What Animals Think and Feel
item.itunes:author: TVO | Steve Paikin
item.itunes:subtitle: Centuries ago animals were seen as unfeeling automatons. The growing science of animal cognition has shattered that assumption. Giraffes appear to grieve. Zebrafish can get depressed. Elephants can classify humans by age, gender, and language. Animals are more intelligent than long assumed, and they have complex emotional lives. But, are they conscious? The Agenda examines new research into the inner lives of animals.
